How Malware Authors Are Incorporating LLMs to Evade Detection

Tech 5 min read

Malware authors are increasingly utilizing large language models (LLMs) to enhance their evasion techniques against security systems. By leveraging the sophisticated capabilities of LLMs, attackers are able to dynamically generate and modify malicious code, making it more difficult for traditional security tools to detect and thwart these threats. Additionally, LLMs can be employed to create convincing phishing messages and automate social engineering attacks, further complicating the defense landscape. As the use of LLMs in cybercrime grows, cybersecurity professionals face

EFF to Arizona Federal Court: Protect Public School Students from Surveillance and Punishment for Off-Campus Speech

Tech 5 min read

The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has appealed to an Arizona federal court to safeguard public school students from being surveilled and penalized for their off-campus speech. The case involves concerns over schools extending their disciplinary reach beyond school grounds into students' private lives, especially regarding social media activities. EFF argues that such practices infringe on students' First Amendment rights and undermine their freedom of expression. By emphasizing the importance of protecting these rights, EFF seeks to establish a precedent that curtails overreaching

Security 5 min read

In the article "Charting the future of SOC: Human and AI collaboration for better security," the author discusses the evolving landscape of Security Operations Centers (SOCs) and the growing importance of integrating artificial intelligence (AI) with human expertise to enhance cybersecurity measures. The piece highlights how AI can effectively handle massive data volumes, detect anomalies, and respond to threats more efficiently than traditional methods.
